cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable,
but I wouldn't want it anymore

Review Overwatch 2? With pleasure! As unfortunately not described on Steam, I had over 600 hours in Overwatch, the classic hero-based shooter from 2016. I loved this game! I loved it with all my heart, until around when Blizzard World was added all the way back in 2018, by that point I had grown tired of the toxic community and the very very headache inducing gameplay. Instead opting to go back to the very game which I had quit playing for Overwatch: Team Fortress 2. Now, that isn't to say that TF2 is perfect, it is very much not, however, I find it to be a much better example of a hero-shooter.

So, what are the issues with Overwatch? This is relevant, please do wait for me to finish critiquing Overwatch, first. The game's visuals had a lot of noise, making it very hard to distinguish between people, weapon effects, the world, and the abilities of Heroes. Every hero will say something when using an ability, especially their "Ultimate", which is an ability with a very long recharge that is supposed to be much more effective during gameplay than the Hero's standard abilities. This causes intense amounts of auditory noise as well. These two issues, when combined, easily overwhelm some players, including myself.

The Heroes of Overwatch lack very much character, save for the original Heroes and the first few Heroes added after launch. For instance, Junkrat is an insane Australian man who is extremely good at handling and making explosives, but Echo is just a robot who copies other Heroes. There isn't much character in these newer Heroes, especially compared to the other Heroes added early on in the game's lifespan.

The maps all look very bland, standard sci-fi affair, to be honest. The artstyle is fair, though it has the aforementioned visual noise issue.

The gamemodes are all bland rehashes of the same gamemodes in many multiplayer first person shooters. There's Payload, Control Points, Hybrid (both of them combined), King of the Hill, Arena (Classic DOOM or QUAKE styled deathmatch), and Capture The Flag. Now, here's the gamemodes in Competitive (as for some fucking reason all games nowadays need to be competitive and not just good old fun): Payload, Control Points, and Hybrid. As one can imagine, this gets boring very quickly. Especially when these concepts are better executed in other games, Team Fortress 2 and Halo 3 come to mind. (By the way, you Overwatch fans, I know they're called Escort, Push, Hybrid, and Control, but the Team Fortress 2 names are better known on Steam so I'm using those.)

A large majority of the Heroes feel like the same hero, just using a different weapon. For instance, Widowmaker and Hanzo do not need to be two separate Heroes. They both use long-range weapons, with their abilities being pretty much dictated by the weapon they are using. I know this is a bit of a stupid take, and I admit that. It's very much a non-issue. But, I feel like I need to bring up the game that Overwatch REALLY wants dead: TF2. In TF2, you have one class that can use a bow or a rifle, his name is Sniper. He can either have a throwable weapon which allows for him or his team to deal much more damage to the person affected, a backpack that reduces sway, a shield that extinguishes him, a shield that helps him with his main counter: Spy, or even just a second gun: an SMG. Notice how Sniper is two different people in Overwatch, thus causing a larger amount of UI clutter. This UI clutter was not an issue on launch, as there were so few Heroes. However, now that there's over 30, there's a huge issue. The Gallery page is damn near impossible to be accurate with your clicks in.

The gameplay itself is nothing special, either. It is like if Rainbow Six Siege met Team Fortress 2, a concept I love. But, Overwatch isn't a good interpretation. The abilities are loud, both visually and auditorily, a lot of the Heroes in Overwatch end up feeling very pointless when there's typically a bunch of other Heroes that do their job better (see Mercy and the rest of the healers, especially Moira), and the maps tend to have zero bearing on the Heroes that a team should be comprised of.

Now for the worst part of the game. I love the game, even with all these faults. But here's the part where I can no longer enjoy the game. The community is full of hateful people, with myself running into large amounts of toxicity for sounding female in VC or for using the pride flag profile pictures. If you do not follow the meta, you get bullied by teammates. If you are bad at the game, your teammates and your enemies will bully you. The community around this game is extremely toxic, and kills the game for me. Honestly, the community for this game is a lot like the companies who made it. Activision Blizzard is a horrible company who abuses their employees, who are full of people who steal mothers' breast milk,  and molests women to the point they feel that death is a better option than continuing on with their lives. And the worst part to me is that absolutely nothing has been done to combat these issues.

Thank you for reading my critique of Overwatch 1, now for Overwatch 2.

Everything I said about 1 applies to 2, literally everything. Don't you worry, though! There's still plenty to cover.

Overwatch 2 is the genuine first game I've played that feels like a cash-grab. I hate season passes, except for the ones in Minecraft Dungeons. See, in Dungeons, you can get the things from prior seasons if you buy to pass, no matter what. Right now, Season 3 is going on, but I can still finish up Season 2 or Season 1. This is how these should be done. Just a small purchase that gives the player an extra amount of reward for playing the game. Well done, Minecraft Dungeons. Overwatch 2 instead chooses to do the standard way: You pay the money and have a limited time to finish it, if you don't, congrats, that money you spent to potentially get the items in the pass is wasted. This is, for obvious reasons, much more predatory than Minecraft Dungeons' method of "pay if you want to and play when you want to."

They added more Heroes to Overwatch 2. Kiriko, on launch (not sure about now), made many Heroes genuinely annoying to play as, and totally ruined the game's balance. There's more clutter in the menus, as well. Their characters are also very bland, like the writing team took the past year off.

They removed a spot from both teams, so now everything is 5V5. See, if you were bad in Overwatch 1, it's fine, there's enough people to make up for it. But now, with one person being gone, being bad is a genuine issue that holds back the team. This, naturally, causes people to be really fucking toxic to new players who just want to play the game or even veterans like me coming back after literal years of balance changes and reworks and new Heroes. Thus leading to people hearing the news that the community is toxic, then avoiding the game because the community is toxic, and the game dying from it. This issue was present with Overwatch 1, and 2 just makes it even worse.

And I have a final issue: This Steam release. It's a spit in my fucking face, that it is. I can't even play it here on Steam. You know why? It fails to link my Battle.net account every single time.

In conclusion, Overwatch 2 is terrible. A mistake. And as the tape keeps rolling, it only burns more. The Invasion update is an example, so much was promised yet such little delivered. At this point, it'd be best if Blizzard refunded purchases made on Overwatch 2 and rolled Overwatch back to before Overwatch 2 was released, as that would be a much better position. Or just release Overwatch 1 as a standalone game and forget about 2, that'd be just as good, if not then better.

This game should not be called a game due to what it drifted away from. Purchasing once and getting everything in the future was the best, Now this thing take more money than your local church just to able to enjoy this cruddy game. The only good thing about this game is the cool community that makes "ART". They work harder than the developers have ever on this game. You could go on the orange and black website and find better cinematics if you just google "Overwatch". Please do not support this game so it can finally burn out. Don't be fooled into purchasing episodes for a game that is dying. Any new addition is more money out of your pocket. Go play fortnite instead to get more value out of your money. One skin for $20, or a blowie from a hooker for $5. Spend your money wisely people.
I know what you did to your players.

I have to say, Overwatch 1 had very little content, but it had soul. Since Jeff Kaplan left, there is no soul anymore, only some coorporative bullshit and mechanics that will try to infenetly drain your money out of your wallet. Locking heroes behind the paywall is crazy. It goes against that core gameplay an puts new players & those who don't want to pay money in a major disadvantage.

Also renaming Jesse McCree is outrageous. I don't care about who he was named after and what that person did, I care about the lore. You can't just randomly rename a character because of some stupid reasons.

The only reason I am leaving thumbs up is because it still has a decent gameplay and because of good memories of the game from 2016, that we've all lost now. 

P.S. Also the fact, that we don't need Battle.net anymore to play this game is ok too.

Great game, caring developer team, but they are forced into making terrible decisions that quite frankly ruin the game. Although I still recommend this game, a lot of the complaints are completely justified. Also, Team Fortress 2 and Overwatch 2 are completely different games, stop comparing them lol

Positives:
-Great gameplay
-A lot of very unique playable characters, theres a hero for everyone :)
-Amazing skins
-PvE is finally out, looks good too, in my opinion.
-The maps look amazing and (most of the time) are fun to play too

Negatives
-New heroes exclusive to the battlepass (takes ages to unlock for free, please just take them out -.- )
-Skins are super expensive, and while they are amazing, they aren't really worth it
-Would prefer more balance patches to quickly fix over/underpowered characters, but they insist on every season having their own 'personality' and 'meta'. Kinda like they want some seasons to be miserable to play?
-After like 4-5 years of waiting, they cancelled skill trees from PvE :(
